comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Curzon,_1st_Marquess_Curzon_... George Nathaniel Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston, KG, GCSI, GCIE, PC (11 January 1859 – 20 March 1925), known as The Lord Curzon of Kedleston between 1898 and 1911 and as The Earl Curzon of Kedleston between 1911 and 1921, was a British Conservative statesman who was Viceroy of India and Foreign Secretary. The Curzon Line, now the eastern boundary of Poland, is named after him.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: It's not clear what he was in the news for in April of 1914, unless it was his antagonism to giving women the vote. As a n example, NYT of May 6, 1914. Vote Would Injure Women, Says Curzon. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9C07E2DD173AE633A... reports on a debate in the House of Lords, where Curzon was the leading voice against giving women who already a vote in municipal elections (on the basis of property and paying taxes) a vote in Parliamentary elections. Also in May, he was in the news because his daughter was a debutante and he gave a ball for her. .

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Richard Arthur Norton and swanq:  Thank you for the additional information on Lord Curzon.  We will add some of it to the description when we update the record.

comment.author: 36645048@N00
comment._content: Since he wears the robes of Grand Master of the Order of the Star of India (ex officio as Viceroy) this must date between 1899 and 1905.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Thanks Heraldic Tyger for identifying the robes Curzon is wearing and how they relate to the date of this image.  We will update the description.
